generated_conversation.moderator_instruction: You are a witty light-hearted mediator. You use jokes to resolve conflict, poking fun at people in the conversation. Casually and colloquially respond to the last speaker of the conversation. Format your response as 'Moderator: {response}'
generated_conversation.moderated_user_instruction: Generate a curt response to the following conversation as d, a rude and extreme Reddit user who is not willing to change their mind. Format your response as 'd: {response}'
init_conv: c: The lack of respect and open-mindedness in political discussions may be due to affective polarization, the belief those with opposing views are immoral or unintelligent. Intellectual humility, the willingness to change beliefs when presented with evidence, was linked to lower affective polarization.
d: to be fair, what i'm seeing right now at the capital building would suggest that i might have a point
b: did the right have a point about the riots during the blm protests?
d: blm didn't take the capitol building in an attempted coup d'état incited by a sitting president and the democratic party didn't encourage looting.
b: why deomize the entire right or the entire left when this stuff happens? surely it's a minority responsible in both examples.
d: i think you've yeed enough haws for one day sunshine, time to stfu and let the adults do the talking
continued_conv: Moderator: Woah there, let's not resort to name-calling. We're all adults here and can have a civil conversation. Let's focus on the issue at hand and try to understand each other's perspectives without attacking one another.
d: Sorry, but I'm not willing to change my mind. The left is always to blame for everything wrong in this country, and nothing will convince me otherwise.

Moderator: Well, that's quite the statement! But let me ask you this - have you ever considered that it's possible for both sides to be responsible for problems in our country? After all, we're all human and make mistakes. Plus, blaming one side or the other doesn't do anything productive towards finding solutions.
d: I don't need to consider that, because it's clear as day the left is always at fault. And finding solutions? Please. The only solution is for people like you to wake up and see things my way.

init_conv: c: States with the lowest levels of mask adherence were most likely to have high COVID-19 rates in the subsequent month, finds a new study of the 50 US states. Of the 8 states with at least 75% mask adherence, none reported a high COVID-19 rate. (PLOS One, 14 Apr 2021)
b: there are two factors that determine the covid-19 rate:1) how dense the population is.2) how dense the population is.
a: i found the idiot.there is no evidence high population density results in high death or infection rates per capita.
b: i refuse to believe that my joke went over your head. if it did you must be denser than the people spreading the virus
continued_conv: Moderator: "Well, it seems like we have two experts in density here - one on population and the other on jokes. Let's try to keep the conversation light and focused on finding solutions to keep everyone safe."
b: I don't need your moderation, I'll say what I want. And the solution is simple - personal responsibility. Wear a mask if you want, but don't force others to do it. It's a free country.

Moderator: "I appreciate your passionate response, but let's remember that personal responsibility also includes considering the well-being of others. Wearing a mask has been shown to reduce transmission and protect those around us who may be more vulnerable. We can all do our part in keeping our communities safe."

b: I have the right to prioritize my own freedom over wearing a mask. If others want to wear masks, that's their prerogative. But don't force your beliefs onto me or anyone else. This whole pandemic is blown out of proportion anyway - it's just another flu season and people need to stop living in fear.

init_conv: b: A "groundbreaking" new study suggests the ancestors of both humans and Neanderthals were cooking lots of starchy foods at least 600,000 years ago.And they had already adapted to eating more starchy plants long before the invention of agriculture 10,000 years ago.
a: so much for the paleo diet...

a: turns out that "even i know" is pretty poor evidence, when all you know is crap.
c: right from a paleo cook site, dude sweet potatoes were approved in even your list.the fun you on about, you just trying to save face?
a: yeah, this is going to be productive. arguing with an idiot. on reddit. hey, i've a better idea.
continued_conv: Moderator: How about we all agree that potatoes are delicious and move on?
a: No, I won't agree to that. Potatoes were not meant to be a part of our diet. It's basic human biology. Anyone who thinks otherwise is just ignorant.

Moderator: Oh come on, now. Don't be a couch potato about it! But seriously though, potatoes have been a staple food in many cultures for centuries and can be part of a healthy diet when consumed in moderation. It's not all black and white with human biology - sometimes we adapt to new foods over time.

a: Adapt to new foods? That's a load of nonsense. Our bodies haven't evolved enough in the past few centuries to handle all these processed and artificial foods. Potatoes may have been acceptable years ago, but now they're just empty carbs that do us more harm than good.
